comments:
Reporter: Brook Zhang
OS:  SLES 9 beta3 & Windows 2003 Standard Edition
Language: CHS/CHT/Korean
Build level: 200404071337(wswb-I20040407-200404121624)   
JDK Version: IBM JDK 1.4.2 Beta
Test case #:    
Summary: The test.release file is not opened in the runtime workbench
 
Description:
Steps to recreate problem:
1-Unzip sef.zip and Import the com.ibm.wsweducation.solution.sef  Plug-in.
2-Open the plug_in.xml and press Depandency Tab , add all plug-in , Save it.
3-Select Run---->workbench and click New.Move to Plug_ins Tab and 
Select "Launch with all workspace and enabled external plug-ins" Then click Run.
4-Create a simple project in the runtime instance of the workbench and copy 
test.release to this project.
5-Double_Click Open this test.release file
 
<<Error>>   
         DBCS:The Error happened and the test.release file is not opened
<<Expected Result>>
         DBCS:The test.release file is opened correctly and the context is 
dispalyed as different colors.

Created an attachment (id=9516)
The Testdata sef.zip

The test.release file is not opened in the runtime workbench

What is the PDE team's intention on this one?  The DBCS testers have flagged 
this one as a critical bug.  We need to get a response back to them.

David, could you please try to recreate this on the latest SLES and Eclipse 
levels?  We think this may be a user error, but want to make sure.

Created an attachment (id=11599)
Screen Shot of error message we received

Jonathan and I both tried to recreate this on a SLES and Windows 2003 machine
respectively.  We had some trouble following your instructions, as we couldn't
add anything on the dependancy tab.

We did proceed to open another workbench and when trying to view the
test.release file, an error message was printed to the screen.	You can see
that screenshot on the attachment.

Testing against 20040610

When I import the plug-in using Import External Plugins I got the following 
exception

java.lang.NullPointerException
	at 
org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.imports.PluginImportOperation.importAsBinar
yWithLinks(PluginImportOperation.java:191)
	at 
org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.imports.PluginImportOperation.importPlugin
(PluginImportOperation.java:121)
	at 
org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.imports.PluginImportOperation.run
(PluginImportOperation.java:80)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run
(Workspace.java:1673)
	at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.Workspace.run
(Workspace.java:1693)
	at org.eclipse.pde.internal.ui.wizards.imports.PluginImportWizard$2.run
(PluginImportWizard.java:104)
	at org.eclipse.jface.operation.ModalContext$ModalContextThread.run
(ModalContext.java:101)

so I couldn't go any further. Did you import it this way?
I used import...->filesystem to import it into a simple project.

Created an attachment (id=11914)
Text.release editor

Tangible evidence that the editor opens correctly in a runtime workbench.

I fixed the NPE reported by my good friend Tod in comment #5, but it is 
unrelated to this defect.

Observations:
1. The project in question is actually setup to be imported using the standard 
import wizard.  It has a hardcoded classpath that does not use classpath 
containers, etc., so it requires tweaking before it compiles.
2. The plugin in question is a 2.1 plugin.  Your target platform needs to be 
2.x-based.  The target platform in comment #4 must have been 3.0 based.  That 
is why you get that error.  A 2.1 plugin needs to go through the cool 
migration wizard before it becomes 3.0 friendly.

Once you set your target platform correctly, and you get your project to 
compile, you can launch a runtime workbench, paste the text file and open it 
in the editor.

> 2-Open the plug_in.xml and press Depandency Tab , add all plug-in , Save it.
I recommend that you never do that.  Gratuitous dependencies severely impede 
classloading performance, and your plugin will be disabled if any of those 
dependencies is missing.
